en: Interview with Zak Goodman-Strauss, 2020-02-22

Interview with Zak Goodman-Strauss, resident of Gatlinburg. Goodman-Strauss recounts the day of the fire with regards to the heavy smoke, and his evacuation from the sudden fire. He also discusses returning to his home despite the city still being closed and the tragedy of finding the body of one victim of the fire. This is a representative quote from the interview: So it's just really smoky in Asheville and super dry in Gatlinburg, though I didn't really think about fire here so much, but there was definitely a lot of fire in the air, you know, at the time. And so, so I'd noticed that. There was definitely fires going on already.

This is a representative quote from the interview: So it's just really smoky in Asheville and super dry in Gatlinburg, though I didn't really think about fire here so much, but there was definitely a lot of fire in the air, you know, at the time. Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Zak Goodman-Strauss, 2020-02-22
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and why you agreed to do this interview, and about your time in Gatlinburg?
What part of Gatlinburg do you live in?
Can you describe what you noticed in the few days leading up to the fire?
Were you in Gatlinburg or Asheville leading up to the fire?
Were you concerned about the smoke at all?
What time of day was this that you were thinking about evacuating?
So you were heading towards Pigeon Forge on the Gatlinburg bound side of the Spur?
Were you planning on going back to Asheville?
Webb Mountain was on fire?
Were you worried about your house at this time?
What prompted you to go to Rocky Top?
So you assumed your house was gone at this point?
Was there any damage to the house?
Did you have power or water when your returned to your home?
The rain hadn't put the fire out completely?
Can you describe what the neighborhood is like?
So you were walking around the neighborhood?
Were there any burns on the body? Do you think he died from exposure?
What went through your mind when you found the body?
Did you ever find out who it was?
Were you ever afraid for your life during the event?
Did you ever have any financial impact form this fire?
Was there any emotional impact form the events?
Was there any emotional impact form the events?
Do you think this fire could happen again?
Have you made any provisions for another fire?
So you haven't taken proactive steps in case of another fire?
Was there anything surprising or good that came from the fire?
Did anything good specifically come from the fire besides the community getting closer?
Do you know a lot of people, or have you spoken with people that have lost their homes?
Were those fires on Husky Grove caused by power lines instead of the fire from the park?
Is there anything else that you would like to share?
